questions.prompt: The p-series ∑(n=1 to ∞) 1/nᵖ converges if and only if:
questions.explanation: The p-series converges if and only if p > 1. When p ≤ 1, the series diverges (including the harmonic series when p = 1).

questions.prompt: For the ratio test, if lim |aₙ₊₁/aₙ| = L < 1, then ∑aₙ:
questions.explanation: The Ratio Test states that if lim |aₙ₊₁/aₙ| = L < 1, then the series converges absolutely.

This is the Absolute Convergence Theorem: if a series converges absolutely (∑|aₙ| converges), then it converges (∑aₙ converges).
The alternating harmonic series converges (by the Alternating Series Test) but not absolutely (since the harmonic series diverges), so it converges conditionally.
The Alternating Series Test states that ∑(-1)ⁿaₙ converges if aₙ ≥ 0, aₙ is decreasing, and lim aₙ = 0.

questions.prompt: A series that converges but not absolutely is said to converge:
questions.explanation: Conditional convergence means ∑aₙ converges but ∑|aₙ| diverges. The alternating harmonic series is a classic example.

questions.prompt: For a conditionally convergent series, rearranging the terms:
options: Can change the sum to any value or cause divergence
Only changes the sum by a constant
questions.explanation: Riemann Rearrangement Theorem: a conditionally convergent series can be rearranged to converge to any desired value or to diverge.

questions.prompt: For the root test, if lim sup |aₙ|^(1/n) = L < 1, then ∑aₙ:
questions.explanation: The Root Test (Cauchy's Test) states that if lim sup |aₙ|^(1/n) < 1, the series converges absolutely.

questions.prompt: The comparison test states that if 0 ≤ aₙ ≤ bₙ and ∑bₙ converges, then:
questions.explanation: The Comparison Test: if 0 ≤ aₙ ≤ bₙ for all n and ∑bₙ converges, then ∑aₙ converges (smaller series converges).

questions.prompt: The limit comparison test compares ∑aₙ and ∑bₙ using:
questions.explanation: The Limit Comparison Test: if aₙ, bₙ > 0 and lim(aₙ/bₙ) = L where 0 < L < ∞, then ∑aₙ and ∑bₙ both converge or both diverge.

questions.prompt: The integral test can be applied to ∑aₙ if:
options: There exists f(x) continuous, positive, and decreasing with f(n) = aₙ
questions.explanation: The Integral Test requires a continuous, positive, decreasing function f with f(n) = aₙ. Then ∑aₙ and ∫f(x)dx have the same convergence behavior.
When the ratio test gives L = 1, the test is inconclusive - the series may converge or diverge. Other tests must be used.
